docs.lead_paragraph: In 1958, as I was turning 17 and my brother 13, our mother died of ovarian cancer. She was only 49 and, until the miserable year that followed the diagnosis, she had never had anything more serious than a cold. She missed many good years as a wife, mother, friend and beloved elementary schoolteacher. Similar tragedies still occur for far too many women who develop ovarian cancer, the fourth leading cause of cancer deaths among American women, after lung, breast and colon cancer. Progress against this disease has been painfully slow, largely because ovarian cancer is hard to find in its early, curable stages, before it has spread beyond its point of origin.

headline.main: The Deadly Whisper of Ovarian Cancer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on ovarian cancer; notes disease is hard to find in its early, curable stages; cites most common symptoms; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Sexuality and Fertility After Cancer,'' by Dr. Leslie R. Schover, John Wiley & Sons, $15.95. Loss of sexual desire is one of the most common results of cancer treatment, and yet that loss and its link to infertility are often ignored by doctors, especially outside the major cancer centers.

headline.main: Rekindling Sexuality for People With Cancer

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews Dr Leslie R Schover's book on treating loss of sexual desire in cancer patients; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The patient, a 38-year-old man at a small hospital in Providence, R.I., was suffering intense pain from a bowel obstruction. But when his doctor recommended an operation, the man refused, saying he was afraid of surgery. Dr. Joan Teno, a member of the hospital's ethics committee, said that even though the man was bright and articulate, with no history of mental illness, his internist thought he did not understand the risk of refusing surgery.
docs.abstract: Some experts say many seriously ill people who seem competent to may actually have imparied abilities to make complicated medical decisions; say impairment often goes unrecognized, leading to regrettable decisions; other experts disagree, holding even most seriously ill patients are able to make decisions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There has been a lot of talk recently about stem cells, and I would find it fascinating even if I didn't have a personal interest. But I do. Millions of my stem cells, 6.85 million to be exact, are sitting in a liquid nitrogen freezer at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.

headline.main: A Handle on Hope, With Thanks to Thalidomide

docs.abstract: Janet Battaile article on her battle with multiple myeloma, bone marrow cancer; cites success of thalidomide in slowing disease; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Children who are overweight and whose blood pressure tends to be a bit high have an increased risk of developing narrowed arteries later in life, Dutch researchers are reporting. The condition, atherosclerosis, greatly increases the risk of heart attack and stroke.

Because of a shortage of donor organs, 50,000 of the 70,000 people in the United States who are awaiting transplants will not get them this year.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a finding that has taken researchers by surprise and alarmed environmentalists, the Mexican government has discovered that some of the country's native corn varieties have been contaminated with genetically engineered DNA. The contaminated seeds were collected from a region considered to be the world's center of diversity for corn -- exactly the kind of repository of genetic variation that environmentalists and many scientists had hoped to protect from contamination. The result was unexpected because genetically modified corn, the presumed source of the foreign genes, has not been approved for commercial planting in Mexico.

headline.main: Genetic Modification Taints Corn in Mexico

docs.abstract: Mexican government, in finding that surprises researchers and alarms environmentalists, finds some of nation's native corn varieties have been contaminated with genetically engineered DNA, even though genetically modified corn has not been approved for commercial planting in Mexico; scientists fear foreign genes, if advantageous, could reduce genetic diversity in native corn varieties; say crop genes may be able to spread across geographic areas and varieties more quickly than expected (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Chained to the Desk: A Guidebook for Workaholics, Their Partners and Children, and the Clinicians Who Treat Them,'' by Dr. Bryan E. Robinson, New York University Press, $16.95. Every so often, most of us put in longer hours on the job to the detriment of family relationships and our own need for relaxation. But does this constitute workaholism?

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at Columbia University, expressing surprise at their own findings, are reporting that women at an in vitro fertilization clinic in Korea had a higher pregnancy rate when, unknown to the patients, total strangers were asked to pray for their success. The findings are in the current Journal of Reproductive Health.

headline.main: A Study Links Prayer and Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Columbia University researchers, surprised at own findings, report women at in vitro fertilization clinic in Korea had far higher pregnancy rate when, unknown to patients, total strangers were asked to pray for their success; had asked members of different Christian denominations abroad to pray for some of women; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With growing concerns about the adequacy of the nation's blood supply, blood bank officials may welcome a new study suggesting that people with an uncommon blood disease can make suitable donors. The study, published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association, looked at people with hemochromatosis, a genetic disorder in which they retain too much iron in their blood. The overabundance of iron can lead to organ damage.

headline.main: Blood Donors With a Need to Give

docs.abstract: National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute study finds people with hemochromatosis, genetic disorder in which they retain too much iron in blood, can make suitable blood donors; blood drawn therapeutically from such people is usually thrown away, even though disease cannot be transmitted through transfusions; researchers say blood is drawn from small percentage of people with disorder at such great volume it could increase blood supply by some 20 percent (S)
